questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the inguinal canal?

choices.text: Conjoint tendon forms a part of the posterior wall
Superficial ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis
Deep ring is an opening in the transverse abdominis
Internal oblique forms both the anterior and superior walls

questions.solution:
The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, not in the transversus abdominis.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

It extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.

Boundaries:

Boundary

 Structures forming

Anterior wall
  • Skin, superficial fascia, external oblique aponeurosis (whole extent)
  • Muscle fibers of internal oblique (lateral 1/3rd)

Posterior wall
  • Parietal peritoneum, extraperitoneal tissues, fascia transversalis (whole extent)
  • Medially reinforced by the conjoint tendon and reflected part of the inguinal ligament

Roof
  • Arched fibers of internal oblique and transversus abdominis forming the conjoint tendon medially

Floor
  • Grooved surface of the inguinal ligament
  • Lacunar ligament at the medial end
 

Deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest (or medial to the pubic tubercle).

questions.text:
All of the following are contents of inguinal canal except _______.
  1. Round ligament
  2. Ilioinguinal nerve
  3. Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve
  4. Spermatic cord
  5. Cremasteric artery
questions.solution:
The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve is not a content of the inguinal canal.

The contents of the inguinal canal include:

  • Spermatic cord in males
  • Round ligament in females
  • Ilioinguinal nerve in both the sexes.

The contents of the spermatic cord include:

  • Cremaster muscle fibers
  • Testicular artery and accompanying veins
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Vas deferens
  • Cremasteric vessels
  • Lymphatics
  • Processus vaginalis

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord contents

Inguinal canal contents:

Male Female
  • Spermatic cord  (with genital branch of genitofemoral nerve)
  • Ilioinguinal nerve
  • Round ligament of the uterus 
  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Ilioinguinal nerve

Spermatic cord contents:

  • Three arteries:
    • Testicular artery
    • Deferential artery
    • Cremasteric artery
  • Two nerves:
    • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
    • Sympathetic nerve fibers
  • Three other structures:
    • Ductus deferens
    • Pampiniform plexus of veins
    • Lymphatic vessels

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form the boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle?
questions.solution:
Vas deferens does not form the boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle.

Hesselbach's triangle (also called the inguinal triangle) is a region of the deep part of the anterior abdominal wall. 

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)

questions.text: A resident while assisting a case of laparoscopic hernia repair observes the surgeon dissect certain anatomical landmarks to expose the triangle of doom. Which of the following does not form a boundary of this triangle?
questions.solution:
Cooper’s ligament does not form the boundary of the triangle of doom.

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The circle of death/Crown of death/Corona mortis:

  • It is a vascular continuation formed by the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels.
  • Accessory obturator artery which is a branch of inferior epigastric artery, arches over Cooper’s ligament and joins the normal obturator artery and forms a complete vascular ring.
  • Injury leads to torrential haemorrhage which is difficult to control.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding inguinal hernia?
  1. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels
  2. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by vas deferens
  3. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis
  4. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas
questions.solution:
The medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by vas deferens and the medial border of the myopectineal orifice is bounded by the lateral border of rectus abdominis.

The triangle of doom is bounded:

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

The myopectineal orifice is an osseo-myo-aponeurotic tunnel. It is through this tunnel that all groin hernias occur. It is bounded:

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: What is the most common type of hernia in females?
questions.solution:
Indirect inguinal hernias are by far the most common type of hernia in women. It is the most common hernia regardless of gender. 

In men, indirect hernias predominate over direct hernias at a ratio of 2:1. Femoral hernia and umbilical hernias are more common in females compared to males at ratios of 10:1 and 2:1, respectively. Although femoral hernias occur more frequently in women than in men, inguinal hernia remains the most common hernia in women.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of swelling in the right groin for the past 6 months. On examination, an irreducible hernia is present in the right groin. Which of the following structures would be helpful in identifying if the hernia is inguinal or femoral in origin?
questions.solution:
Pubic tubercle is used to differentiate between inguinal and femoral hernias.

Inguinal hernia is above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

Femoral hernia is below and lateral to the pubic tubercle.

Another structure that is useful in differentiating between inguinal and femoral hernia is inguinal ligament. An inguinal hernia leaves the abdominal cavity just above the inguinal ligament and a femoral hernia leaves just below the inguinal ligament.

The position of inguinal hernia in relation to pubic tubercle is controversial. In Bailey, its mentioned as above and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Whereas other surgery books mention as above and medial to the pubic tubercle. This has been discussed with Dr. Rohan Khandelwal and we will stick to above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

questions.text: An elderly male patient is diagnosed with direct inguinal hernia. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: The sac lies medial to the inferior epigastric artery
Cough impulse is felt on the index finger
Can descend till the bottom of scrotum
The neck is narrow and is prone for strangulation

questions.solution:
The sac and contents of a direct hernia protrude through Hesselbach’s triangle, i.e., medial to the inferior epigastric artery.

questions.text: Bubonocele is a type of _________.
questions.solution:
Bubonocele is a type of indirect inguinal hernia where the hernia is limited to the inguinal canal.

Indirect inguinal hernia is more common on the right side because of the delay in atrophy of the processus vaginalis after the normal slower descent of the right testis to the scrotum during fetal development.

Related Pearl: Types of indirect inguinal hernia

  • Bubonocele – Hernia limited to the inguinal canal.
  • Funicular – Hernia stops just above the testis.
  • Complete/scrotal – Hernia reaches bottom of scrotum.

questions.text: What is the most common serious complication expected to occur in patients with hernia?
questions.solution:
Strangulation is the most common serious complication of a hernia. 

An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia.An incarcerated hernia can lead to a bowel obstruction or strangulation. Obstruction is characterized by colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, abdominal distension and obstipation. Features of obstruction along with vascular compromise is seen in strangluation. Strangulation occurs in 1% to 3% of groin hernias. It is more common at the extremes of life.

Most strangulated hernias are indirect inguinal hernias. However, femoral hernias have the highest rate of strangulation (15% to 20%) of all hernias, and it is, therefore, recommended that all femoral hernias be repaired at the time of discovery. Tenderness is the first sign of strangulation.

The first step is the correction of hypovolemia. The treatment of choice is immediate surgery. The fundus is opened first during surgery.

questions.text: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia, for which Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for its management.

The contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medial to the inferior epigastric artery and the deep inguinal ring. Whereas, the contents of an indirect hernia protrude lateral to the inferior epigastric artery. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the deep inguinal ring obliquely towards the superficial inguinal ring and then to the scrotum.

A direct hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach triangle, which is a zone of weakness for direct hernias. 

A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to bridge the defect in this repair.

Other surgical methods used for the repair of an inguinal hernia are:

  • Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament. 
  • Shouldice repair - It is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate.
  • Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) - It is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia
  • McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament.
  • Stoppa-Rives repair - It is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal space.
  • Herniotomy - It is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done.

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese male patient presented with bilateral, large inguinal hernias. He had been operated on for hernia twice in the past and is now posted for Stoppa's repair.  Which of the following statements regarding this procedure is false?

choices.text: This procedure refers to open preperitoneal hernia repair
The mesh is placed in the retromuscular space
The mesh needs to be sutured to the posterior rectus sheath in case of small defects
This procedure is based on the principle of Pascal's law

questions.solution:
With smaller defects, the mesh does not need to be sutured in Stoppa's repair.

This is based on Pascal's law. Pascal’s law states that any additional pressure exerted on an enclosed fluid mass is transmitted equally in all directions.The abdomen is an enclosed space and intra-abdominal pressure is distributed equally over the mesh, thereby keeping the mesh in place.

Stoppa's repair is an open preperitoneal mesh repair primarily indicated for large, recurrent, bilateral hernias.

In Stoppa’s mesh repair, a large piece of mesh is placed in the retro muscular space, over the posterior rectus sheath or peritoneum. This mesh is not sutured in patients with small defects because it is held in place by intra-abdominal pressure (Pascal’s law). This allows the eventual incorporation of the mesh with the surrounding tissues. Alternatively, in larger defects, the mesh can be secured laterally with several sutures.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with a history of a reducible and painless swelling in the right groin for the past 2 months. After the clinical and radiological investigations, the diagnosis of a right-sided inguinal hernia was made. The patient is posted for hernia repair surgery. Which of the following steps will not be done in this patient during the repair?
questions.solution:
Inguinal hernia in a child is treated by herniotomy. In this procedure, repair of the inguinal ring is not done.

This is because the inguinal hernia in the pediatric population is due to the presence of patent processus vaginalis and not due to the weakening of the abdominal muscles or the ligaments.

Herniotomy involves either reduction of the hernial sac alone, or opening of the hernial sac, reduction of the contents, transfixation of the neck, and excision of the patent processus vaginalis/ hernial sac.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate mesh used in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.

Lightweight meshes generally contain less material and induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, which results in better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.

Meshes with large pores exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging, which allows increased soft tissue ingrowth. They have greater elasticity and flexibility and also shrink less resulting in lesser adhesions, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient discomfort and pain. So the best mesh type among the given options is lightweight mesh with large pores.

Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological depending on their composition.

Synthetic meshes are made from polypropylene, polyester, or PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene). 

POLYPROPYLENE POLYESTER PTFE
monofilament multifilament solid
hydrophobic hydrophilic hydrophobic
rigid elastic rigid

PTFE meshes are hydrophobic with a lower risk of adhesion.

Biological meshes are acellular matrix materials derived from humans or animals and have lesser complications. But due to poor collagen deposition and absorption, they rapidly lose mechanical strength and hence their use is restricted to infected environments. 

Note: To promote better tissue integration, a composite mesh was developed which combines the attributes of polypropylene and PTFE by layering the two substances on top of one another.

questions.text: A patient operated for direct inguinal hernia developed sensory loss at the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation in the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the ilioinguinal nerve. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury.

The iliohypogastric nerve carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve in the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in direct inguinal hernia. Iliohypogastric nerve can also get injured following appendicectomy.

Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females. 

Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with chronic constipation is diagnosed with Type 7 Gilbert hernia. This refers to ______
questions.solution:
Femoral hernia is classified under type 7 Gilbert hernia.

As per Nyhus classification system, femoral hernia is classified under type 3C.

Related Pearl: Modified Gilbert's classification of hernia

Type 1 Indirect hernia with peritoneal sac passing through an intact internal ring that will not admit 1 fingerbreadth (ie,<1 cm.); the posterior wall is intact.

Type 2 Indirect hernia (the most common indirect hernia) with peritoneal sac coming through a 1-fingerbreadth internal ring (ie, ≤2 cm.); the posterior wall is intact.

Type 3 Indirect hernia with peritoneal sac coming through a 2-fingerbreadth or wider internal ring (ie, >2 cm.).They are frequently complete and often have a sliding component. They begin to break down a portion of the posterior wall just medial to the internal ring.

Type 4 Direct hernia with full floor posterior wall breakdown or multiple defects in the posterior wall. The internal ring is intact, and there is no peritoneal sac.

Type 5 Direct hernia with a diverticular defect. There is no peritoneal sac and the internal ring remains intact.

Type 6 Both direct and indirect inguinal hernia (a pantaloon hernia)

Type 7  Femoral hernia.

Related Pearl: Nyhus classification of groin hernia

  • Type I - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring normal (e.g., pediatric hernia)
  • Type II - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated but posterior inguinal wall intact; inferior deep epigastric vessels not displaced
  • Type III - Posterior wall defect
    • A- Direct inguinal hernia
    • B - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated, medially encroaching on or destroying the transversalis fascia of Hesselbach triangle (e.g., scrotal, sliding, or pantaloon hernia)
    • C - Femoral hernia
  • Type IV - Recurrent hernia
    • A - Direct
    • B - Indirect
    • C - Femoral
    • D - Combined

questions.text: Which of the following statements about femoral hernia is true?

choices.text: All femoral hernias should be repaired
Femoral vein lies medial to the sac

questions.solution:
All femoral hernias should be repaired and incarcerated femoral hernias should have the hernia sac contents examined for viability.

Option A: Femoral hernia occurs in both males and females, but it is more common in multiparous females. Femoral hernia is more common on the right side because of the tamponading effect of the sigmoid colon on the left femoral canal. This effect is absent on the right side.

Option C: The incidence of strangulation in femoral hernias is high because of the narrowness of the neck of the sac and rigidity of the femoral ring.

Option D: Femoral vein is situated lateral to a femoral hernia (femoral canal).

Related Pearl: Anatomy of Femoral Canal

questions.text: In Laugier’s hernia, the opening is in the _____
questions.solution:
Laugier’s hernia is an atypical femoral hernia where the sac herniates through a gap in the lacunar (Gimbernat’s) ligament.

Related Pearl: Variants of femoral hernia

Laugier’s femoral hernia:

  • Through a gap in lacunar (Gimbernat) ligament.
  • Always strangulated

Narath’s femoral hernia:

  • Seen in patients with congenital dislocation of hip
  • It is behind the femoral vessels

Cloquet’s hernia:

  • Sac lies under pectineus fascia.

Hesselbach’s hernia:

  • Lateral to femoral artery

Serafini's hernia:

  • Behind the femoral vessels

Velpeau(Prevascular/Teale's) hernia:

  • Infront of femoral vessels

Beclard’s hernia:

  • Through saphenous opening

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Spigelian hernia is false?

choices.text: It occurs above the level of the arcuate line
The hernia sac is posterior to the external oblique aponeurosis
Most commonly presents as a painless mass

questions.solution:
Usually, Spigelian hernias do not present as a mass because it is beneath the intact external oblique aponeurosis.

The most common presentation in Spigelian hernia is pain.

There is a common misconception that they protrude below the arcuate line owing to the deficiency of the posterior rectus sheath at that level; but in fact, the defect is almost always above the arcuate line.

Related Pearl: Spigelian hernia/Hernia of linea semilunaris:

  • Occurs through the spigelian fascia, which is the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. 
  • This aponeurotic layer is  between the rectus muscle medially and semilunar line laterally.
  • Occur at or above the arcuate line.
  • Often interparietal, with the hernia sac dissecting pos­terior to the external oblique aponeurosis.
  • In subumbilical region and is due to defect in internal oblique.
  • Clinical feature:
    • Often present with localized pain in the area without a bulge because the hernia lies beneath the intact external oblique aponeurosis. 
  • Diagnosis: Ultrasound or CT of the abdomen.
  • Treatment – surgery

questions.text: While performing an elective hernia repair, the surgeon notices that the posterior wall of the hernia sac is formed by the sigmoid colon. What is this type of hernia known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of a sliding hernia.

Sliding hernia occurs when an internal organ composes a portion of the wall of the hernia sac.

The most common viscus involved are as follows:

  • Left side: sigmoid colon and its mesentery
  • Right side: cecum

It is more common on the left side. Most sliding hernias are variants of indirect inguinal hernias. The primary danger associated with a sliding hernia is the failure to recognize the visceral component of the hernia sac resulting in injury to the bowel or bladder.

Option A: A lumbar hernia is a posterolateral body wall hernia where the bowel, omentum, or pre-peritoneal fat herniates through the lumbar triangles. 

Option C: A Spigelian hernia occurs through slit-like defects in the anterior abdominal wall adjacent to the semilunar line. Most spigelian hernias occur in the lower abdomen where the posterior sheath is deficient. It is also called “spontaneous lateral ventral hernia” or “hernia of the semilunar line”.

Option D: A pantaloon hernia occurs when both a direct and an indirect hernia develop on the same side of the groin. The hernia is named pantaloon because the two hernia sacs are divided by epigastric vessels, and so they look like a pair of pants.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient underwent adrenalectomy for Cushing's syndrome one year back. He now presents with a history of chronic lower back pain. On examination, a partially reducible mass that increased in size during Valsalva maneuver was noticed on his lower back. Which of the following statements regarding the patient's condition is false?

choices.text: Herniation may have occured through the Grynfelt’s triangle
The inferior lumbar triangle is bound by the external oblique and latismus dorsi muscle
Herniation is relatively more common on the right side
Dowd Ponka technique is  used for surgical repair

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an iatrogenic lumbar hernia which developed due to weakening of the posterior abdominal wall due to surgery. It occurs more commonly on the left side.

A lumbar hernia is a posterolateral body wall hernia where the bowel, omentum, or pre-peritoneal fat herniates through the lumbar triangles. Causes can be congenital, acquired, traumatic, or iatrogenic. It is frequently confused for lipomas, muscle strains, fibromas, abscesses, and kidney tumors.

Related Pearl: Lumbar triangles and hernia

  • Acquired>congenital
  • Left side> right side

Superior lumbar triangle (Grynfelt triangle) - Bounded by the

  • 12th rib
  • Paraspinal muscles
  • Internal oblique muscle.

Inferior lumbar triangle (Petit triangle) - Bounded by the

  • Iliac crest
  • Latissimus dorsi muscle
  • External oblique muscle. 

Dowd’s operation is done for lumbar hernia

questions.text: Which type of hernia is depicted in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
The diagram shows Maydl’s hernia/Hernia-en-W/retrograde hernia, where 2 loops of the bowel remain in the hernia sac with the connecting loop inside the abdomen.

Option A: In Richter's hernia, a small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia. Strangulation can occur without the pres­ence of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

Option B: In Littre’s hernia, Meckel’s diverticulum is the content. Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option C: Petersen hernia is caused by the herniation of intestinal loops through the defect between the small bowel limbs, the transverse mesocolon, and the retroperitoneum, after any type of gastrojejunostomy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old fit athlete presents to the OPD with complaints of nausea and heartburn. On examination, a soft, pea-sized swelling could be palpated on his abdomen. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is epigastric hernia, also known as fatty hernia of linea alba.

Epigastric hernia is located between the xiphoid process and umbilicus, usually in the midline. It occurs more commonly in males. A soft midline swelling can be felt more easily than seen. Pain occurs due to the incarceration of the preperitoneal fat and may simulate peptic ulcer. There is no overlying sac.

questions.text: An 83-year-old lady was brought to the OPD with a two-day history of nausea, thigh pain and obstipation. Her family reported a significant weight loss over the last year attributed to grieving over her son's death. On examination, there is no lump in her groin. But, she experiences pain along the anteromedial aspect of her thigh which is relieved by thigh flexion. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is true?

choices.text: Femoral hernia is the most likely diagnosis
Howship Romberg sign can be elicited
Transinguinal approach is preferred for surgery
These hernias are almost always interparietal

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and examination findings are suggestive of obturator hernia. Howship-Romberg sign can be seen in patients with obturator hernia.

Howship-Romberg sign refers to pain in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh due to compression of the obturator nerve that is relieved by thigh flexion.

Obturator hernia is also known as skinny old lady hernia and French hernia. It occurs more commonly in thin, elderly, debilitated females.

Predisposing factors are:

  • Women with wider pelvis and more triangular obturator canal
  • Malnutrition
  • Chronic constipation
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
  • Multiparity
  • Ascites
  • Kyphoscoliosis

Intestinal obstruction can occur.

Option A: Femoral hernias commonly present as a small lump in the groin. They may be asymptomatic or present with strangulation in about 30% of patients.

Option C: A posterior approach, open or laparoscopic surgery is the treatment of choice. This approach provides direct access to the hernia.

Option D: Interparietal hernias are rare and occur when the sac lies between layers of the abdominal wall. These hernias most frequently occur in previous incisions. Spigelian hernias are almost always interparietal.

questions.text: Hernia with hydrocele is known as ________.
questions.solution:
Gibbon’s hernia is a hernia with hydrocele.

Option B: Berger’s hernia is hernia into the pouch of Douglas.

Option C: Beclard’s hernia is femoral hernia through the opening of the saphenous vein.

Option D: Ogilvie’s hernia is hernia through a defect in conjoint tendon just lateral to where it inserts with the rectus sheath.

Edward Gibbon, the author of "The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire," was greatly embarrassed by a large hydrocele. The second time that it was tapped, it became infected, and Gibbon died a few days later. The hydrocele was associated with a large scrotal hernia which had probably been punctured.

questions.text: According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 incisional hernia refers to:
questions.solution:
According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 incisional hernia refers to umbilical hernia.

According to the European Hernia Society classification of incisional hernias:

Midline incisional hernias are classified as-

M1 Subxiphoidal
M2 Epigastric
M3 Umbilical
M4 Infraumbilical
M5 Suprapubic

Lateral incisional hernias are classified as-

L1

Subcostal
L2

Flank
L3

Iliac
L4

Lumbar

questions.text: A young female patient who had been suffering from chronic abdominal pain is rushed to the casualty due to acute exacerbation. On further investigations, she is diagnosed with intestinal obstruction secondary to a paraduodenal hernia. Which  of the following statements regarding the hernia is false?

choices.text: Left-sided hernia is found in the fossa of Landzert
Right sided hernia is found in the fossa of Kolb
It is more common on the right side

questions.solution:
Paraduodenal hernia is more common on the left side (75%).

Option A: In Left-sided paraduodenal hernia, bowel herniates through the fossa of Landzert. 

Option B: In right-sided paraduodenal hernia, bowel herniates through the fossa of Waldeyer/Kolb. 

Both the fossa of Landzert and the fossa of Waldeyer/Kolb are formed due to congenital mesenteric fusion defects.

Option C: Paraduodenal hernia is the most common internal hernia and they are usually congenital.

questions.text: An infant who is diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism presents with the following hernia. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this child?

choices.text: The hernia may spontaneously resolve by 2 years of age
Surgical repair is indicated if the hernia persists for more than 5 years of age
Strangulation is a common complication associated with this hernia in this child
Mayo’s procedure or mesh repair can be done for this hernia

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of congenital hypothyroidism and the image showing a mass protruding out of the umbilicus are indicative of an umbilical hernia. Obstruction and strangulation are uncommon below the age of 3 years.

Mayo’s operation is done for umbilical hernia. A small curved incision is made below the umbilicus and the neck of the sac is opened. The contents are returned to the peritoneal cavity and the redundant sac is excised after closing it. Defect in the linea alba is closed with interrupted sutures. Indications for surgery in umbilical hernia are:

  • Defect size >2cm
  • Persisting beyond 5 years
  • Progressively enlarging after 2 years of age (usually regresses spontaneously by 2 years of age)
  • Symptomatic
  • Strangulated

In adults, defects up to 2cm in diameter may be sutured primarily with minimal tension. However, with larger defects, mesh reinforcement will be beneficial.

questions.text: A baby was born with a congenital defect as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce before 7 weeks
Topical application of silver nitrate is done

questions.solution:
The congenital defect showing herniation of the intestinal contents enclosed in a sac from the umbilicus is suggestive of omphalocele. It is due to the failure of the physiological hernia to reduce into the abdominal cavity before 10 weeks resulting in non-closure of the umbilical ring. 

Physiological herniation of the midgut through the umbilicus occurs during the 5th week so as to accommodate the rapidly growing intestine and persists until the 10th week.

Omphalocele is seen in term babies and is usually associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of α-fetoprotein.

An omphalocele may contain the stomach, liver, and intestines. These contents are enclosed in a sac. 

The treatment is as follows:

  • Preservation of the intact sac with a sterile, moistened, saline gauze or transparent bowel bag.
  • IV fluids should be started, along with gastric tube decompression and IV antibiotics.
  • Topical application of povidone-iodine ointment, merbromin (mercurochrome), or silver nitrate allows the sac to thicken and epithelialize gradually.
  • Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects. 

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes

Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presented with umbilical discharge. Abdomen examination was normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step is the USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous or fistula and it's connections. 

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities: Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between the yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets obliterated. The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct leads to various abnormalities depending on which part of the duct remains patent.

  • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula.
  • Persistence of the distal end near the umbilicus leads to the umbilical polyp or sinus.
  • Persistence of the distal end with mucus retention leads to the cyst, which may be associated with the intestine or the umbilicus by a fibrous band.
  • A fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to an enterocutaneous fistula.

Patent urachus occurs due to the failure of urachus to obliterate, resulting in a connection between the bladder and the umbilicus.

Urachal cyst occurs when the urachus fails to obliterate but there is no connection between the bladder and the umbilicus.

The given image below shows a urachal cyst (UC) attached to Meckel’s diverticulum (MD) on one side and urinary bladder (UB) on the other side with a patent tract- urachus (U).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly seen tumor in the retroperitoneal space?
questions.solution:
Liposarcoma is the most commonly seen tumor in retroperitoneal space.

Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant. Malignant retroperitoneal tumors may be mesodermal (75%), neuroectodermal (24%), or embryonic remnant (1%) in origin. Rarely it can be urologic or metastatic also. The order of frequency of primary retroperitoneal malignancy is as follows:

  • Liposarcoma
  • Leiomyosarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Fibrosarcoma
  • Malignant nerve sheath tumors

Liposarcoma is composed of three histologic varieties (listed in order of decreasing frequency):

  • Well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma
  • Pleomorphic liposarcoma
  • Myxoid/round cell liposarcoma 

Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while the well-differentiated is the least malignant. Myxoid liposarcoma has intermediate malignant behavior.

Diagnosis is confirmed by contrast-enhanced CT with CT of the chest to look for metastases. 

Surgery is the main modality of treatment. Wide excision with complete en bloc dissection is done. Post-operative radiotherapy and chemotherapy are used as adjuvant methods. Radiotherapy is given at a dose of 5000 cGY, it can be external beam or intra-operative radiotherapy. Chemotherapeutic agents used are mesna, adriamycin, ifosfamide and dacarbazine (MAID regimen).
